newsitem.title: SIERRA LEONE: Song guides Afro-American grandma to her roots.
newsitem.headline: Song guides Afro-American grandma to her roots.

text.p: An African American grandmother arrived in Sierra Leone on Thursday on a quest for her roots, guided by a song taken to the Americas by an ancestor captured by slavers over two centuries ago.
Mary Moran, 75, from Harris Neck, South Corolina, traced her family's origins to the south of the former British colony in West Africa via the song -- which is in the local Mende language.

Hundreds of well-wishers, including government officials, turned out at Freetown's Lungi International Airport to welcome her. Officials poured libations to celebrate and consecrate her return to the mother country.
"Mrs Moran knows an ancient song in her family passed down from mother to daughter for over 200 years," said a statement issued by the Sierra Leone authorities in advance of the visit.
Moran, accompanied by 14 sons, daughters and grandchildren, was due to visit the village of Senehun Ngola to meet Baindu Jabati, a Sierra Leonian woman traced by researchers with the aid of the song.
Researchers played a recording of the song in numerous Mende villages in the south without anybody recognising it before they finally stumbled on Jabati, who learned the song from her grandmother.
The two women are due to sing the song together in the village on Friday.
The U.S. embassy said that Moran was from the Gullah community of coastal South Carolina, a distinctive group of African Americans.
Slavers took many ancestors of the community to the Americas from what was called the Rice Coast, the traditional rice growing region that is now Sierra Leone.
The Gullah community has preserved traditional foods -- rice dishes and okra soup -- which are still eaten in Sierra Leone.
Sierra Leone, independent since 1961 but racked by civil war since 1991, was set up under British protection in 1787 by opponents of slavery for freed slaves.

Moran was to meet President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, who took office in March 1996 after multi-party elections ended four years of army rule. Tejan Kabbah has signed a peace deal with the rebels but implementation is proving difficult.
